title: How to Make an International Call to Mexico (from Anywhere)

steps.title: Dial your country's exit code.
steps.content: Dial your country's exit code. In order to call a number outside of your own country, you need to start with an exit code. Some countries share the same exit code as others, but there is no single exit code that can be used for all countries. Example: If you're calling Mexico from the United States, you'd start with the US exit code, which is 011, and your number should look like this: 011-[country code]-[area code]-[local number]

steps.title: Dial "52," the country code for Mexico.
steps.content: Dial "52," the country code for Mexico. After dialing the exit code, you'll need to dial Mexico's country code, which is 52 . Example: If you were calling Mexico from the United States, your number should look like this so far: 011-52-[area code]-[local number]

steps.title: Dial the area code.
steps.content: Dial the area code. Every region in Mexico has its own 2- to 3-digit area code. Area codes are necessary for both mobile and landline calls. If your contact didn't supply the area code with their local number, use Google or your favorite search engine to find the correct one. Example: If you're dialing a person in Mexico City, the area code is 55 . Your number should look like this so far: 011-52-55-[local number]

steps.title: Dial the rest of your contact's local phone number.
steps.content: Dial the rest of your contact's local phone number. The final part of the phone number is the contact's local number. Mexican phone numbers with area code and local number are always 10 digits long, so local numbers are always 7 to 8 digits long. [1] X Trustworthy Source Federal Communications Commission Independent U.S. government agency responsible for regulating radio, television, and satellite, and phone communications Go to source Example: If your contact's number is 5555-5555, the finished number should look like 011-52-55-5555-5555

steps.title: Exit codes vary by country.
steps.content: Exit codes vary by country. We've made a list of all of the exit codes used around the world, but this list is not exhaustive. To make sure you have the right exit code, check Google or your favorite search engine. [2] X Research source 011 is the exit code for the United States, Canada, a number of US territories, and a number of Caribbean islands. 00 is the exit code for almost all of Europe, the Middle East, Africa, and South America, as well as some Asian countries. Some countries, such as South Korea, Colombia, Brazil, Israel, Finland, and Indonesia use 00 but also allow or require extra digits to specify your carrier. 0011 is the exit code for Australia. No other countries are currently using 0011 as an exit code. 010 is the exit code for Japan, and it's the only country that currently uses this code. 001 is used by Guyana, Hong Kong, Mongolia, Thailand, and Cambodia. 002 is used by Taiwan. 0 is used by Samoa and Turks and Caicos. 000 is used by Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, and Singapore. 009 is only used by Nigeria. 1XX0 is used in Chile, where the "XX" changes depending on your phone carrier. 19XX is the exit code for Peru, where the "XX" is replaced by a specific carrier code. 810 is the exit code for a number of countries in east Europe: Belarus, Kazakhstan, Russia, Tajikistan, and Turkmenistan. 99 is the exit code for North Korea.
